<!-- Explain, in a clear and concise way, the command you ran and the result you were trying to achieve.
Example: "I ran `spack find` to list all the installed packages and ..." -->

I am currently building out a new software stack for our site, with a few different microarchitecture targets. I run `spack clean --all` before each target build. At some point, during the build of any target architecture, a failure will occur. At first the messages were lock related but it seemed related to the number of open files. I did not capture the exact message. I then bumped the limit for the number of open files and then get the following:
```
==> Error: Exception occurred in writer daemon!
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/packages/gpjohnsn/argon_stack/spack/lib/spack/llnl/util/tty/log.py", line 747, in _writer_daemon
    rlist, _, _ = _retry(select.select)(istreams, [], [], 1e-1)
  File "/opt/packages/gpjohnsn/argon_stack/spack/lib/spack/llnl/util/tty/log.py", line 830, in wrapped
    return function(*args, **kwargs)
ValueError: filedescriptor out of range in select()
==> Error: ProcessError: Command exited with status 1:
```

Since `select()` is limited to monitoring 1024 descriptors the error makes sense, although I am wondering why so many are open. To sum up, it was initially running out of file descriptors and failing. Ensuring more open files are possible then leads to an out of range, >1024, error in select(). It seems that files are not getting closed.

### Steps to reproduce the issue
Install a large number of packages in an environment. In my case, 1268 packages.
### Error Message

<!-- If Spack reported an error, provide the error message. If it did not report an error but the output appears incorrect, provide the incorrect output. If there was no error message and no output but the result is incorrect, describe how it does not match what you expect. -->

* **Spack:** 0.16.1-2153-8d52200
* **Python:** 3.6.8
* **Platform:** linux-centos7-cascadelake
* **Concretizer:** original

title: building a "large" number of packages in environment fails with file descriptor error
